title: Matthew Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 20.

questions.question: What did the householder agree to pay the labourers for working in his vineyard?
options: A penny a day
Two pennies a day
Half a penny a day
No payment
questions.correctAnswer: A penny a day
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:2 states that the householder agreed with the labourers for a penny a day.

questions.question: At what hour did the householder first go out to hire labourers?
options: The third hour
Early in the morning
The eleventh hour
The sixth hour
questions.correctAnswer: Early in the morning
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:1 describes the householder going out early in the morning to hire labourers.

questions.question: How did the householder pay the labourers who were hired last?
options: A penny
Two pennies
Half a penny
Nothing
questions.correctAnswer: A penny
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:9 says those hired about the eleventh hour received every man a penny.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the first labourers when they received their wages?
options: They murmured against the goodman of the house
They were joyful and thankful
They gave some wages to others
They left immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They murmured against the goodman of the house
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:11 explains that when the first labourers received their pay, they murmured against the goodman of the house.

questions.question: Who did Jesus say would be 'first' and 'last' in the kingdom of heaven?
options: The last shall be first, and the first last
The greatest shall be the least
The rich shall inherit the earth
The wise shall lead the foolish
questions.correctAnswer: The last shall be first, and the first last
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:16 states that the last shall be first, and the first last in the kingdom of heaven.

questions.question: What did Jesus predict would happen to him in Jerusalem?
options: He shall be betrayed, condemned, mocked, scourged, crucified, and rise again
He will become king of Israel
He will perform many miracles there
He will write new scriptures
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be betrayed, condemned, mocked, scourged, crucified, and rise again
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:18-19 records Jesus predicting his betrayal, condemnation, mockery, scourging, crucifixion, and resurrection on the third day.

questions.question: Who came to Jesus asking for their two sons to sit at his right and left in his kingdom?
options: The mother of Zebedee's children
Mary Magdalene
The mother of Peter
A Pharisee woman
questions.correctAnswer: The mother of Zebedee's children
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:20 tells us that the mother of Zebedee's children came to Jesus with this request.

questions.question: What did Jesus ask the sons of Zebedee about drinking his cup and baptism?
options: If they were able to drink of his cup and be baptized with his baptism
If they wanted to be healed
If they would follow him to Jerusalem
If they would teach others
questions.correctAnswer: If they were able to drink of his cup and be baptized with his baptism
questions.explanation: In Matthew 20:22, Jesus questioned the sons of Zebedee about their ability to drink his cup and be baptized with his baptism.

questions.question: How did the other ten disciples react to the request of the two brothers?
options: They were moved with indignation
They rejoiced for them
They ignored the request
They asked Jesus for their own positions
questions.correctAnswer: They were moved with indignation
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:24 states that the ten disciples were moved with indignation against the two brothers.

questions.question: According to Jesus, who should be great among his followers?
options: Whosoever will be great should be their minister
Those with the most wealth
Those with the longest prayers
Those who perform miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Whosoever will be great should be their minister
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:26 says that whoever wants to be great among the disciples should be their minister.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said he came to be ministered unto, not to minister.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:28 explains that Jesus came to minister and give his life as a ransom, not to be ministered unto.

questions.question: True or False: Two blind men cried out to Jesus for mercy as he passed by Jericho.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:30-31 describes two blind men crying out to Jesus for mercy as he passed by Jericho.

questions.question: True or False: The multitude encouraged the blind men to keep crying out louder to Jesus.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:31 shows that the multitude rebuked the blind men, asking them to be silent, but they cried out all the more.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'So Jesus had compassion on them, and ______ their eyes.'
options: touched
healed
blessed
anointed
questions.correctAnswer: touched
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:34 says Jesus had compassion and touched their eyes, which immediately received sight.

questions.question: Who did the householder call to give the labourers their hire?
options: His steward
The labourers themselves
The Pharisees
The disciples
questions.correctAnswer: His steward
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:8 says the lord of the vineyard instructed his steward to call the labourers and give them their hire.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels they have served God longer than others yet sees others receiving equal blessings. Based on Matthew 20, what biblical truth would you share about God's generosity?
options: God rewards all according to His grace and purpose, not human comparison.
God only blesses those who serve the longest.
God favors those who work hardest in the vineyard.
God punishes those who complain about others' blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: God rewards all according to His grace and purpose, not human comparison.
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:1-16 teaches that the householder pays all laborers the same wage regardless of hours worked, showing God's generosity is not based on human merit but grace. Verses 13-15 emphasize God's right to be gracious as He wills.

questions.question: According to Matthew 20, what attitude should a Christian have toward serving others in the church?
options: Serve humbly, considering others above yourself.
Serve only if it benefits you personally.
Seek positions of power to gain authority.
Serve only when commanded by a leader.
questions.correctAnswer: Serve humbly, considering others above yourself.
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches in Matthew 20:25-27 that greatness in God’s kingdom is shown by humble service, not by exercising authority over others. True leadership is marked by being a servant.

questions.question: How does Matthew 20 teach us to respond when we feel overlooked or less honored compared to others?
options: Trust in God's plan and remain faithful without envy.
Demand equal recognition by complaining.
Seek to outshine others by your own efforts.
Withdraw from service to avoid disappointment.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's plan and remain faithful without envy.
questions.explanation: The parable of the laborers (Matthew 20:1-16) shows that God's reward is based on His grace, not human comparison. Believers are encouraged to accept His justice with contentment and trust.

questions.question: When Jesus foretells His suffering and death in Matthew 20, what practical lesson can believers learn about enduring trials?
options: Endure suffering with faith because it is part of God's redemptive plan.
Avoid trials at all costs to maintain comfort.
Suffering means God has abandoned you.
Only the strong can endure trials successfully.
questions.correctAnswer: Endure suffering with faith because it is part of God's redemptive plan.
questions.explanation: In Matthew 20:17-19, Jesus predicts His suffering, death, and resurrection, teaching that trials have purpose in God's kingdom and believers should persevere in faith.

questions.question: A believer seeks to know how to exercise leadership in their community. According to Matthew 20, what biblical principle should guide their leadership style?
options: Lead by serving others with humility and selflessness.
Lead by asserting authority and power over others.
Lead by distancing yourself from those you serve.
Lead by demanding obedience without explanation.
questions.correctAnswer: Lead by serving others with humility and selflessness.
questions.explanation: Jesus contrasts worldly leadership with kingdom leadership in Matthew 20:25-28, teaching that true leaders serve others as He did, giving their lives for the people.

questions.question: What does the parable of the laborers in the vineyard teach about fairness and contentment in our work and service?
options: God’s fairness may differ from human expectations; be content with His provision.
Fairness means everyone must receive exactly the same reward.
Only the longest workers deserve reward.
Complaining ensures a better reward from God.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s fairness may differ from human expectations; be content with His provision.
questions.explanation: The parable (Matthew 20:1-16) shows that God's fairness is based on His generosity, not human standards. Workers are called to be content and trust God's justice.

questions.question: In Matthew 20, when the mother of Zebedee’s children asks for her sons to sit at Jesus’ right and left, what is Jesus teaching about ambition and God's kingdom?
options: True honor in God’s kingdom is granted by the Father, not earned by ambition.
Ambition is the key to receiving favor from God.
Only family members of Jesus will have special places.
Positions of honor are given to those who ask first.
questions.correctAnswer: True honor in God’s kingdom is granted by the Father, not earned by ambition.
questions.explanation: Jesus replies in Matthew 20:22-23 that the places of honor are prepared by the Father, indicating that ambition alone does not determine rank in God’s kingdom.

questions.question: How does Matthew 20 encourage believers to pray and trust God when facing difficult requests or desires in their spiritual life?
options: Pray with faith but accept God’s will, which may differ from our wishes.
Pray only for things you are sure God will grant.
Demand God’s blessing without considering His plan.
Avoid prayer if unsure about God’s response.
questions.correctAnswer: Pray with faith but accept God’s will, which may differ from our wishes.
questions.explanation: Jesus’ response to the request in Matthew 20:22 teaches believers to trust God’s wisdom and purposes, even when His answer differs from our desires.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 20, Jesus came to be served and to receive honor from others.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:28 states that Jesus came not to be ministered unto but to minister and give His life as a ransom, emphasizing humility and service.

questions.question: True or False: The parable in Matthew 20 shows that God’s kingdom operates on human fairness and equal effort rewards.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The parable (Matthew 20:1-16) reveals that God’s kingdom is governed by grace and generosity, not by human concepts of fairness or equal effort.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When the two blind men cried out to Jesus, they called Him "_____" as a recognition of His messianic role.
options: Son of David
Lord of Hosts
King of Kings
Son of God
questions.correctAnswer: Son of David
questions.explanation: In Matthew 20:30-31, the blind men call Jesus 'O Lord, thou Son of David' acknowledging Him as the promised Messiah, a title that expresses faith in His power to heal and save.

questions.question: A believer struggles with jealousy toward others who seem to receive more blessings. What practical advice from Matthew 20 can help them overcome this struggle?
options: Remember that God’s grace is given according to His will, and be thankful for what you have.
Compare your blessings with others to motivate yourself.
Demand equal blessings through persistent prayer.
Avoid fellowship with those who have more blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: Remember that God’s grace is given according to His will, and be thankful for what you have.
questions.explanation: The parable of the laborers (Matthew 20:1-16) teaches believers to trust God's fairness and be content with His generosity, discouraging envy and promoting gratitude.

questions.question: Based on Matthew 20, how should Christians view and practice humility in family and church life?
options: Practice humility by serving others and avoiding selfish ambition.
Seek to be the most honored in family and church for validation.
Ignore the needs of others and focus on personal success.
Only serve when asked directly by leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Practice humility by serving others and avoiding selfish ambition.
questions.explanation: Jesus' teaching in Matthew 20:25-27 encourages humility expressed through service, rejecting worldly ambition in both family and church contexts.

questions.question: What does Matthew 20 teach about perseverance in faith when facing ridicule or rejection?
options: Keep calling on Jesus with faith even when others discourage you.
Stop praying to avoid embarrassment.
Rely on your own strength rather than faith.
Give up if others mock your faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Keep calling on Jesus with faith even when others discourage you.
questions.explanation: The story of the blind men (Matthew 20:30-31) shows their persistence in crying out to Jesus despite rebuke from the crowd, modeling faithful perseverance.

questions.question: How does Matthew 20 illustrate the importance of faith in Jesus for spiritual healing and transformation?
options: The blind men’s faith in Jesus as Son of David leads to their healing and following Him.
Jesus heals only those with perfect faith.
Faith is unnecessary; healing is automatic.
Only the disciples received healing from Jesus.
questions.correctAnswer: The blind men’s faith in Jesus as Son of David leads to their healing and following Him.
questions.explanation: In Matthew 20:30-34, the blind men’s faith in Jesus’ messianic identity brings healing and results in their discipleship, showing faith’s transformative power.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 20.

questions.question: In the parable of the laborers in the vineyard, what does the 'penny' represent in the cultural context of Matthew 20?
options: A day's wage
A temple tax
A Roman coin of no value
A special offering
questions.correctAnswer: A day's wage
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:2 states the laborers agreed for a penny a day, which in the historical context refers to a typical day's wage for a laborer in ancient Judea.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in the parable of the laborers about the order of payment?
options: Chiasm
Parallelism
Irony
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:8-16 uses a chiasm structure where the last are paid first and the first last, highlighting reversal of expectations, a common Semitic literary form.

questions.question: What theological theme does the phrase 'the last shall be first, and the first last' in Matthew 20:16 most clearly illustrate?
options: God's justice
Divine election
The kingdom's reversal of worldly values
Universal salvation
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom's reversal of worldly values
questions.explanation: The phrase in Matthew 20:16 reflects a key New Testament theme where God's kingdom upends social and hierarchical expectations.

questions.question: Who is the 'householder' in the parable of the vineyard commonly interpreted to represent?
options: God the Father
Jesus Christ
The Apostle Paul
King Herod
questions.correctAnswer: God the Father
questions.explanation: In Matthew 20:1-16, the householder is typically understood as God the Father who calls laborers into His kingdom.

questions.question: In Matthew 20:17-19, Jesus foretells His suffering. Which Old Testament passage is most closely alluded to in this prophecy?
options: Isaiah 53
Psalm 23
Genesis 22
Exodus 12
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah 53
questions.explanation: Jesus' prediction of betrayal, suffering, and resurrection in Matthew 20:17-19 parallels the suffering servant described in Isaiah 53.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'cup' Jesus refers to in Matthew 20:22-23?
options: A symbol of suffering and divine wrath
A cup of blessing at Passover
A royal chalice
A ritual cleansing cup
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of suffering and divine wrath
questions.explanation: The 'cup' metaphor in Matthew 20:22-23 alludes to suffering and judgment, a concept found in Psalm 75 and Jeremiah 25.

questions.question: How does Jesus redefine greatness among His followers according to Matthew 20:25-27?
options: By serving others
By accumulating wealth
By political power
By military strength
questions.correctAnswer: By serving others
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches in Matthew 20:25-27 that true greatness is demonstrated through humility and service, contrasting worldly views of power.

questions.question: What Christological title is used by the two blind men in Matthew 20:30-31 when asking for mercy?
options: Son of David
Messiah
Rabbi
Son of God
questions.correctAnswer: Son of David
questions.explanation: The blind men address Jesus as 'Son of David' (Matthew 20:30-31), a Messianic title rooted in Jewish expectation of a Davidic king.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus healing the two blind men immediately after they call out to Him?
options: It fulfills prophecy about the Messiah
It demonstrates His political power
It signifies the cleansing of the temple
It shows His rejection by the Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfills prophecy about the Messiah
questions.explanation: Jesus healing the blind (Matthew 20:34) fulfills Isaiah 35:5-6 prophecy about the Messiah restoring sight to the blind.

questions.question: The phrase 'and to be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with' in Matthew 20:22 is a metaphor for what?
options: Suffering and death
Ritual cleansing
Holy Spirit reception
Water immersion
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering and death
questions.explanation: Jesus uses 'baptism' metaphorically in Matthew 20:22 to describe the suffering and death He must endure, foreshadowing His passion.

questions.question: Which cultural practice informs the laborers' expectation of reward in the parable in Matthew 20?
options: Day labor wage agreements
Sacrificial offerings
Temple tithing
Roman taxation
questions.correctAnswer: Day labor wage agreements
questions.explanation: The laborers' expectation of payment in Matthew 20:2-10 reflects common day labor wage customs in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: In Matthew 20:28, Jesus states He came to give His life as a ransom. What Old Testament concept does this most closely connect with?
options: The Passover lamb
The Day of Atonement
The Jubilee year
The Ark of the Covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The Passover lamb
questions.explanation: Jesus’ ransom concept in Matthew 20:28 echoes the Passover lamb's sacrificial role in Exodus 12, symbolizing redemption.

questions.question: True or False: In Matthew 20, the mother of Zebedee's children requests that her sons be seated on Jesus' immediate right and left in His kingdom.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:21 records the mother of Zebedee's children asking Jesus to grant her sons positions at His right and left in the kingdom.

questions.question: What is the reaction of the other ten disciples when the two brothers ask for the seats of honor, and what does this reveal about group dynamics?
options: They were indignant, revealing jealousy
They were supportive, showing unity
They were indifferent, showing apathy
They were confused, showing misunderstanding
questions.correctAnswer: They were indignant, revealing jealousy
questions.explanation: Matthew 20:24 reports the ten disciples' indignation, highlighting human jealousy and rivalry even among Jesus' followers.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus taking the twelve disciples aside to speak privately in Matthew 20:17?
options: To prepare them for His impending passion
To announce His resurrection
To appoint a new leader
To teach them a new parable
questions.correctAnswer: To prepare them for His impending passion
questions.explanation: In Matthew 20:17, Jesus privately informs the disciples of His forthcoming suffering and death to prepare them spiritually.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does the parable of the labourers in the vineyard (Matthew 20:1-16) primarily teach about the kingdom of heaven?
options: God's sovereign grace and generosity in salvation
The necessity of works to earn salvation
The importance of early church leadership
The exclusivity of the chosen people
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign grace and generosity in salvation
questions.explanation: The parable illustrates God's sovereign choice to give equal reward to all labourers regardless of their time of service, highlighting grace rather than works (Matthew 20:1-16). This is consistent with Romans 9:15-16, Ephesians 2:8-9, John 1:12-13, and Psalm 84:11, teaching salvation is by God's mercy and not human merit.

questions.question: In Matthew 20:18-19, Jesus predicts His suffering. What theological theme is primarily revealed in this prophecy?
options: The atoning sacrifice of Christ for sin
The political overthrow of Israel
The establishment of an earthly kingdom
The rejection of the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: The atoning sacrifice of Christ for sin
questions.explanation: Jesus foretells His betrayal, condemnation, crucifixion, and resurrection, highlighting His role as the suffering servant who atones for humanity's sins (Isaiah 53:4-6, Psalm 22, Mark 10:45, 1 Peter 2:24). This is foundational to Christian soteriology.

questions.question: What does Jesus mean when He says, 'the last shall be first, and the first last' in Matthew 20:16?
options: God reverses human expectations about status in His kingdom
The firstborn will inherit more blessings
The Gentiles will be excluded
Only the elders will be saved
questions.correctAnswer: God reverses human expectations about status in His kingdom
questions.explanation: This statement reveals the reversal of worldly values in God's kingdom, where humility is exalted and pride humbled (Luke 1:52, James 4:6, 1 Corinthians 1:27-29, Isaiah 66:2). It emphasizes God's sovereign judgment.

questions.question: How does Matthew 20:26-28 redefine the concept of greatness and leadership among Jesus’ followers?
options: True greatness is marked by servanthood and humility
Greatness is achieved through political power
Leadership requires wealth and influence
Only priests can be leaders
questions.correctAnswer: True greatness is marked by servanthood and humility
questions.explanation: Jesus contrasts worldly dominion with kingdom leadership, teaching that greatness is serving others as He did (Philippians 2:5-8, Mark 9:35, John 13:12-17, 1 Peter 5:3). This challenges notions of authority and power.

questions.question: What does the request of the mother of Zebedee’s children (Matthew 20:20-21) reveal about human ambition in relation to the kingdom of God?
options: It shows a misunderstanding of the nature of Christ’s kingdom
It highlights correct expectations of messianic power
It demonstrates immediate acceptance of Jesus’ mission
It reveals the Gentile dominion over Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It shows a misunderstanding of the nature of Christ’s kingdom
questions.explanation: The request for seats of honor reflects a worldly view of power, which Jesus corrects by teaching about suffering and servanthood (Matthew 20:22-23; Mark 10:35-45). This reveals the tension between human ambition and divine purpose.

questions.question: According to Matthew 20:22-23, what is the 'cup' Jesus refers to, and what does it symbolize?
options: The suffering and sacrificial death He must endure
A celebratory drink at the messianic banquet
A symbol of political authority
The Holy Spirit's baptism
questions.correctAnswer: The suffering and sacrificial death He must endure
questions.explanation: The 'cup' symbolizes the suffering Jesus will undergo for salvation (Psalm 75:8, Isaiah 51:17, Luke 22:42, Mark 10:38). Drinking the cup signifies participation in His passion and obedience to God's redemptive plan.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus’ statement in Matthew 20:28, 'the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many'?
options: It reveals the servant nature and atoning purpose of Christ’s mission
It affirms Jesus’ right to earthly kingship
It predicts the destruction of the temple
It establishes the law as the path to salvation
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals the servant nature and atoning purpose of Christ’s mission
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes Jesus’ humility and substitutionary atonement (Isaiah 53:10, Mark 10:45, 1 Timothy 2:5-6, Hebrews 9:28), affirming His divine mission to save humanity through self-sacrifice.

questions.question: In the healing of the two blind men (Matthew 20:29-34), what messianic title do they use to address Jesus, and what is its significance?
options: Son of David, affirming Jesus as the promised Messiah
Son of God, affirming divinity
Rabbi, affirming Jesus as teacher
Prophet, affirming His role in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Son of David, affirming Jesus as the promised Messiah
questions.explanation: Calling Jesus 'Son of David' acknowledges His messianic lineage and fulfills Old Testament promises (2 Samuel 7:12-16, Isaiah 11:1, Jeremiah 23:5, Luke 1:32). This title expresses faith in His kingly and redemptive role.

questions.question: What does the complaint of the first hired labourers in Matthew 20:11-12 reveal about human attitudes toward divine justice?
options: Tendency to envy God’s grace toward others
Joyful acceptance of God’s generosity
Recognition of equal merit among all
Indifference to rewards
questions.correctAnswer: Tendency to envy God’s grace toward others
questions.explanation: The labourers grumble because they expect greater reward, revealing human envy and misunderstanding of grace (James 3:14-16, Proverbs 14:30, Romans 12:15, Galatians 5:26). God’s justice often transcends human fairness.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Is thine eye evil, because I am good?' (Matthew 20:15) teach about God's sovereignty?
options: God has the right to dispense grace as He wills
God must distribute rewards equally by human standards
God’s goodness depends on human approval
God is obligated to reward works
questions.correctAnswer: God has the right to dispense grace as He wills
questions.explanation: This rhetorical question asserts God's sovereign right to show mercy and grace (Exodus 33:19, Romans 9:14-24, Psalm 115:3, Daniel 4:35), challenging human begrudging attitudes toward divine generosity.

questions.question: How does the vineyard owner’s method of payment in Matthew 20:8-10 illustrate the nature of God's kingdom economy?
options: God’s grace is not based on human effort or time served
Wages are strictly proportional to hours worked
Only early believers receive full reward
God rewards only the most faithful
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace is not based on human effort or time served
questions.explanation: Paying all labourers equally regardless of hours worked symbolizes the unmerited nature of salvation (Ephesians 2:8-9, Titus 3:5, Romans 11:6, Isaiah 55:1-3). It teaches that God's kingdom operates on grace rather than merit.

questions.question: What theological truth is highlighted by Jesus’ question to the blind men, 'What will ye that I shall do unto you?' in Matthew 20:32?
options: Faith involves asking and receiving from Christ
Jesus only helps those who are silent
Miracles require no human response
Physical healing is the main purpose of Jesus' mission
questions.correctAnswer: Faith involves asking and receiving from Christ
questions.explanation: Jesus’ question invites an expression of faith and desire, showing the importance of petition in receiving divine blessing (Mark 10:51, James 1:6-7, Luke 18:41, John 9:38). It underscores human dependence on Christ’s mercy.

questions.question: What does the steward’s role in Matthew 20:8 indicate about God’s administration of grace?
options: God entrusts others to dispense His grace justly
Grace is distributed randomly without order
Grace is earned through stewardship
Only angels distribute grace
questions.correctAnswer: God entrusts others to dispense His grace justly
questions.explanation: The steward acts on behalf of the householder, illustrating God’s delegated authority in administering gifts (1 Corinthians 4:1, Luke 12:42-48, Romans 12:6, Ephesians 4:11-12). This reflects divine order in grace distribution.

questions.question: How does the parable of the vineyard labourers relate to the doctrine of election?
options: It affirms God's sovereign choice in salvation
It denies the existence of election
It teaches salvation is based on works
It limits salvation to Israel only
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God's sovereign choice in salvation
questions.explanation: The parable shows that God chooses whom He will to receive salvation freely (Romans 9:11-16, Ephesians 1:4-6, John 15:16, Deuteronomy 7:7-8). Election is a display of mercy, not human achievement.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implied by Jesus' statement in Matthew 20:21 regarding 'sitting on his right and left in his kingdom'?
options: The future messianic reign and reward of believers
Immediate political rule in Jerusalem
The end of the world within that generation
The cessation of suffering in this life
questions.correctAnswer: The future messianic reign and reward of believers
questions.explanation: The request anticipates the eschatological kingdom where believers will share in Christ’s authority (Daniel 7:13-14, Revelation 3:21, 1 Corinthians 6:2-3, Luke 22:29-30). It points to glorification and eternal reward after resurrection.
